Text:
Alaskan excellence turns 100! Join me in wishing a HAPPY BIRTHDAY to James J. Carey, a WW II veteran living in Hoonah. I'm grateful for his military service ‚Äì he truly exemplifies the "Greatest Generation." 

May God Bless you, James! 

https://t.co/bLr4DFdBST via @JuneauEmpire

Other adversaries like China, Iran, and North Korea are watching. They are taking notes on how we respond, which is why we must firmly and decisively stand up to Putin in defense of Ukrainian sovereignty.
Unfortunately, President Biden waited for Putin to be breathing down Ukraine‚Äôs neck before taking action.
This week, President Biden finally announced sanctions against Russia, but why did it take so long? This is not only a crisis for freedom-loving people in Ukraine, but a test for our nation.
There is no reason for America and our allies to rely on Russian energy exports when we can produce it right here at home.

I am pleased that today, Germany halted the certification of Nord Stream 2. This is a positive development, but we need to project American leadership to counter Putin. The time is now to truly unleash Alaska ‚Äì and America's ‚Äì energy sector.

The completion of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline would put many countries in Europe further under the thumb of the Russian government by making them more dependent on Russia for their energy needs, thus further emboldening Putin and his cronies.

In 2021, the Biden Admin waived sanctions on the Russian company building the Nord Stream 2 pipeline & its Chief Executive. Just last month, Senate Democrats hypocritically used the filibuster to keep Nord Stream 2 pipeline sanctions from reaching the 60-vote margin for passage.

Putin's push for an invasion of #Ukraine is an egregious act that must be condemned and responded to. As the situation evolves, I continue monitoring developments in the region. This is the time to stand with the Ukrainian people against this unprovoked & undemocratic assault.

Happy #PresidentsDay! 

Today, we recognize those who led the nation in our highest office. Having served w/ more than 1 in 5 U.S. Presidents throughout my career, I've been blessed w/ countless opportunities to stand up for Alaska every time I have a meeting at the White House. https://t.co/ztXQlo702P
Pictured: Black whalers posing for a photo at Point Barrow, c. 1890s, courtesy of the National Park Service and the University of Alaska

During #BlackHistoryMonth we celebrate Black history in Alaska & our nation. From whalers and homesteaders, to soldiers & more, the Last Frontier is home to countless Black trailblazers. Read Black History in the Last Frontier by the @NatlParkService: https://t.co/dJpTRpJbXV https://t.co/DQZNhhLAZR

I continue working to ensure this dark era is never forgotten. This Congress, I'm a proud co-sponsor of legislation to preserve confinement sites and to continue educating Americans, particularly young people, of the wrongful forced roundup of our fellow citizens.
It was my honor to attend the bill signing, which included my legislation to acknowledge this terrible wrong and provide compensation for Japanese Americans and the Alaska Natives from the Aleutians.

In 1988, I proudly helped pass the Civil Liberties Act. I worked hard to ensure it included comprehensive restitution for both Japanese Americans and the Alaska Natives who suffered at the hands of this egregious government policy.
For years, these innocent people were forced to live in poor conditions, often without clothes, plumbing, or electricity.

The grave injustice of internment reached Alaska as well. In 1942, hundreds of UnangaxÃÇ people from nine villages in the Aleutians were forced onto cramped transport ships as they watched their homes and churches set ablaze.
Interning our Japanese American neighbors was an evil act that not only deprived them of their life and property, but also their dignity.

Growing up, I remember attending local Farm Bureau meetings with my father. I will never forget how he courageously stood publicly against the Japanese American internment, repeatedly pointing out that these were our fellow citizens and friends. 

#DayofRemembrance üßµ https://t.co/xa9pe9bX0i https://t.co/T0NCfyvtBP

Today, we lost my friend @RepHagedorn. He was a fighter & a good man who cared deeply about his constituents. His father, my former colleague Rep. Tom Hagedorn, should be very proud of Jim‚Äôs accomplishments. Anne & I are praying for Jim‚Äôs wife Jennifer, Tom, & the entire family.

Alaska Natives on the Aleutian Islands were also forcibly removed & interned during this terrible period. The Civil Liberties Act of 88 included my bill to provide restitution for the Aleut people who had their livelihoods & property stolen by the gov't. https://t.co/amvO8vE0C9 https://t.co/xa9pe9bX0i https://t.co/wQ1lfdKHFJ

Tomorrow is the #DayOfRemembrance, marking 80 years since FDR's E.O. 9066, authorizing Japanese American internment. This is a dark stain on us; it must never happen again. In '88, I spoke on the House Floor in support of the Civil Liberties Act to recognize this grave injustice. https://t.co/fUoS3YVSoH

For those of us who hunt wild game, including moose, I have always advocated utilizing ALL of the animal, especially the fat. 

This weekend in Anchorage, my buddy Frank Forpahl gave me some quality moose fat he harvested himself, and I‚Äôll put it to good use! https://t.co/KMPr0BcI2l https://t.co/ji9pmmGIBF

I had a lot of great constituent meetings this week, including some with four-legged friends at the Alaska Chapter of Paws for Purple Hearts! This good boy & his pals do great work for veterans w/PTS, traumatic brain injuries, & other trauma-related conditions. @paws4ph üá∫üá∏üê∂ https://t.co/ZY5ILpg1nP

As Ranking Member of the Subcommittee for Indigenous Peoples, I‚Äôm not going to give up on any Natives! I‚Äôm proud to stand w/ Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, & Indigenous people in the Lower 48. 

More: https://t.co/3p81RcXpcU

Watch my @NCAI1944 fireside chat w/@RepGwenMoore‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/kR639P1KAX
In the meantime, I encourage you to learn more about Alaska‚Äôs kelp harvesters and their impressive operations here: https://t.co/7YgDUFGJBf

Unfortunately, our pro-kelp amendment was not supported by my Democratic committee colleagues, and I strongly condemn passage of legislation with provisions harmful to Alaska. I voted NO on the overall bill and will continue working to ensure it does not become law.

Kelp could be a game changer when it comes to renewables. My Democratic colleagues have long opposed petroleum-based goods; Kelp is renewable & is used in cosmetics, disposable packaging, biofuels & more. Why would my colleagues on the left oppose these Alaska-grown renewables?

AK's kelp industry provides good jobs & is a valuable source of food and manufacturing material. Today, at a Natural Resources Committee markup, I voted YEA on an amendment offered by my friend, @RepBentz, to remove anti-kelp harvesting provisions supported by Democrats. [THREAD] https://t.co/lsjxfhYkQL

On Elizabeth Peratrovich Day, we honor the life and legacy of Alaska‚Äôs ‚Äúfighter in the velvet gloves.‚Äù Her steadfast commitment to standing up to bigotry led to Alaska‚Äôs Anti-Discrimination Act of 1945 ‚Äî the first state or territorial anti-discrimination law in the United States. https://t.co/F8mtUsMscb

I just met with the Alaska chapter of @paws4ph! These steadfast advocates and their four-legged friends play a crucial role in assisting veterans with PTS, traumatic brain injury, and other trauma-related conditions. I'm grateful for the work they do on behalf of our heroes! üá∫üá∏üêï https://t.co/EfwDWCd4Vw

This weekend, I attended the Annual Hope Auction, which raises funds for Hope Community Resources to improve the lives of Alaskans w/intellectual and developmental disabilities, traumatic brain injuries, & mental health challenges. Thanks to everyone who made this event possible! https://t.co/9EtvvlaTVo

I want to thank my good friend @RepGwenMoore for joining me for a Congressional Fireside Chat on Tribal lands and economies w/ @NCAI1944. I‚Äôm a steadfast advocate for Tribal sovereignty and will always stand up for Indigenous Peoples‚Äô right to self-determination! https://t.co/2R3Bqm2CAN

We had a wide-ranging discussion on topics such as resource development, whaling, & ensuring AK Native voices are heard in D.C. I'm proud of everything our Native Corporations have accomplished on behalf of their communities, and I'll continue standing up for them in Congress.

.@ASRC_AK is a major contributor to AK's economy & an important example of the success of ANCSA. I recently met with ASRC Pres & CEO Rex Rock, Sr and Board Chair Crawford Patkotak to receive an update on ASRC's operations & the vital services they offer their shareholders. https://t.co/Zb8i2A81Jh

This week, I hosted leaders from villages in the NANA region in my DC office. I appreciated our discussion covering topics like resource development and the Postal Service. ANCs are crucial to AK Native well-being & I appreciate the work NANA does on behalf of their shareholders! https://t.co/NGib6edX7D

Higher ed can help expand opportunity, but too many kids experiencing homelessness or the foster care system face unique barriers to a college career. I think that's wrong.

I intro'd a bill w/ @RepKClark to break down the barriers for these kids. More: https://t.co/sJvBC0h8Wwüßë‚Äçüéì https://t.co/Y8IjjeoIgS

Today, it was my honor to help pass the Postal Service Reform Act. Whether it's medication, packages, or any other mail, USPS is a vital lifeline to Alaskans. I'll keep fighting so that USPS can deliver for my constituents for years to come. More here: https://t.co/xvQs0LjXvy https://t.co/A11c3EEpK8

üö®BREAKINGüö®

I just spoke in support of the Postal Service Reform Act. USPS is crucial & if you don't think so, try living in areas of Alaska without roads! This bipartisan bill helps bring financial stability to USPS so they can deliver to my constituents for years to come.üì´‚úâÔ∏è https://t.co/YvOmEQlOGH

I'm serious when I say the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is a game changer for Alaska! Thanks to @J_blackwell99, @jorgieak49, and @EmilySnodgrass4 for penning an @adndotcom op-ed in support of the Alaska Delegation's work on the bill.

Read it here: https://t.co/p7AG5GiWvP

Today, it was my pleasure to meet with @AleutCorp's new President & CEO Skoey Vergen and Communications Director Kate Gilling. I'm wishing Skoey all the best in his presidency, and I look forward to working with him. 

Thank you for stopping by! https://t.co/t3uraCY4Ve

#OTD 111 years ago, President @RonaldReagan was born. It was an honor to serve with him, and his wise words continue to guide my service to Alaska:

"Freedom is never more than one generation away from extinction. It has to be fought for and defended by each generation." https://t.co/Gh1Z2wRXeH

I will reiterate what I said last year: I was appalled at the violence and destruction at the Capitol on January 6th. What transpired was criminal, un-American, and cannot be considered legitimate protest.

I truly believe I have the best staff in Congress, and I wanted to introduce you to my DC team. When you call my office, these are the committed staffers who are always ready to hear from Alaskans.

Click here to meet them: https://t.co/A0tPn5DArl https://t.co/d2nGKcn9wN

Click here to participate in my Roundtable: https://t.co/aAIsG8SNeh https://t.co/LFr9U62a9g

Today, I addressed members of the AK House Labor & Commerce Committee on funding from the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law. Here's the truth: despite what you may have heard, AK will receive $6700 per resident ‚Äì that means we do better than any other state! 

My full testimony‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/svsn73WOx1

It's my great honor to welcome Anderson Tran to my D.C. office! Anderson will serve on behalf of all Alaskans as my 2022 @NOAA Sea Grant Fellow. In his role, he'll be working on issues related to fisheries, oceans, and other marine policy.

Join me in extending a warm welcome! https://t.co/3NjBOKUSiO

It's a busy day in DC! I attended a crucial Transportation and Infrastructure Committee hearing on the rollout of 5G and its potential impacts on aviation. 

As the rollout continues, I‚Äôm working to make sure it doesn‚Äôt adversely impact flight operations. https://t.co/QCXbghptUh

To remaining members of ISIS and would-be leaders, you are on watch. Our second-to-none military will not hesitate to make you pay for the atrocities you have committed against humanity. 

My full statement following today's elimination of the leader of ISIS‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/qgJwMeqXJ6

I encourage you to read the full letter for yourself ‚Äì nowhere in it will you see anything about capping the salaries of our hardworking nurses.

You can find the full letter here: https://t.co/D3vvs8PzZb

There is absolutely NOTHING in the letter advocating for capping nurse pay, which I do not support. Travel nurses have saved countless lives in this pandemic, and I want to make sure their agencies are treating them with the honesty, transparency, and respect they deserve.
The letter we sent to the White House is simply asking for an investigation to determine if any of these agencies are acting unscrupulously.
This is wrong, and if it is indeed happening, America's nurses are getting caught in the crossfire between staffing agencies and the potentially exorbitant rates they charge hospitals.

My wife is a nurse & I've always supported the hardworking nurses in AK & beyond. Unfortunately, Congress has received reports that some nurse staffing agencies ‚Äì NOT the nurses themselves ‚Äì have been inflating prices and taking large cuts to the detriment of nurses and patients.

There is much disinformation on a bipartisan letter I joined w/ my friends @PeterWelch (D-VT) & @RepMGriffith (R-VA). The letter, which deals w/ executives at nurse staffing agencies, has been falsely characterized as "capping nurse pay." 

Let‚Äôs set the record straight. [THREAD] https://t.co/Q5Ogab5jFm

I just addressed @ANHB‚Äôs Mega Meeting via Zoom.

Tribal health care providers need funding certainty. I continue pushing my colleagues to not only support @IHSgov funding, but also to help move my bill to allow for advance IHS appropriations. Thanks to ANHB for having me! https://t.co/9tjN9MvDeN

Access to traditional Indigenous foods is crucial. Programs like WIC should empower Native communities to tailor nutrition as they see fit. I intro'd the INFANT Act to implement crucial reforms & I'm proud to have @Sealaska's support on the bill. https://t.co/fcEWf0XxoA https://t.co/z3vcQaVwc1

I'm very relieved to hear that Rep. Ron Gillham of Kenai is recovering following a sudden heart attack. 

Ron - get well soon, Anne and I are praying for your continued recovery! 

https://t.co/BHZazjLqqY

Whether it's our robust oil & gas operations on the North Slope or communities like Kodiak running almost entirely on wind and hydropower, we must keep Alaska's energy momentum going! https://t.co/mRJYM7tDOp
I'm wishing a Happy #LunarNewYear to all who celebrate ‚Äì in Alaska and around the world! May 2022 bring your family prosperity, happiness, and good health. https://t.co/uTlWV7EHWA
Read more about the Care is an Economic Development Strategy (CEDS) Act: https://t.co/nefzRqih5j

61% of Alaskans live in "child care deserts," & that's unacceptable. A lack of child care stifles economic empowerment for too many. Our working families need access to safe, dependable child care. 

My CEDS Act w/@RepNikema will expand child care access to help families thrive. https://t.co/C4EkUZuCcq

Alaskans: sound off on infrastructure! I just launched my Alaskan Infrastructure Roundtable, a fully online platform where you can share your infrastructure priorities directly with me. I want to hear from you!

I want to make sure USPS receives on-the-ground information from Alaskans. If you are having difficulties, do not hesitate to contact me so I can deliver feedback directly to USPS: https://t.co/8XtYRtw1L2

Residents of McCarthy can go to https://t.co/vmx33CXdQi & navigate to the FAQ. On that page, there is info that is potentially helpful for multi-family situations like McCarthy. On this page, a service request can be filed, or tests can be ordered via telephone at (800) 275-8777.

Finally, I am hearing from constituents in McCarthy, Alaska who are having issues ordering kits as their mail is delivered weekly via Glenallen. I have raised this issue with USPS leadership and have received some new guidance:

They have also advised me that those with residential PO Boxes should now be able to order their tests kits. If you experienced a problem previously, I ask you to try again today. At the moment, business PO Boxes continue to be ineligible for orders.
USPS has informed me that they are aware of the challenges individuals in multi-unit apartment buildings are experiencing when attempting to order tests and they hope to have a resolution soon.

While many Alaskans have been successful in ordering COVID-19 rapid tests from the federal government, I continue seeking answers from the Administration and USPS for those still experiencing issues. üßµ https://t.co/QbKhwOnVAj

Alaska Natives and other Indigenous trappers shouldn't be criminalized for the trapping they've been doing for centuries. The so-called Refuge From Cruel Trapping Act threatens to make a simple expression of their traditions a criminal act. 

I'm fighting hard to stop it. https://t.co/URKGWWbANA

For millennia, Alaska Natives have been providing for their families by trapping. Unfortunately, the so-called Refuge From Cruel Trapping Act includes no exemption for our Indigenous trappers, and that's wrong! 

This week, I questioned @USFWS's Stephen Guertin on this BAD bill. https://t.co/msd9QsOXmw

It's a busy day in DC! I just wrapped up an interview about the Arctic's strategic importance with @DefenseOne's @jacqklimas. 

We must foster expertise in this ever changing region, which is why I've worked hard to establish the Ted Stevens Center for Arctic Security Studies. https://t.co/CHjhYWO2NB

Thanks to @AKNewsNow for covering my efforts to ensure Alaskans can secure COVID-19 rapid tests through @USPS as smoothly as possible. 

Watch the segment featuring Alaska Chief Medical Officer @annezinkmd below, and read my letter to the Admin here: https://t.co/JDtN1YZmca https://t.co/DgjhoEcLmE

üö®BIG news for AK! üö®

Nearly $1 BILLION in infrastructure money is headed to our state. From the Port of Nome expansion & the Lowell Creek Flood Diversion project, to the Moose Creek Dam & Kenai River erosion efforts, this is a game changer for AK. More: https://t.co/NRt3X1zAIw https://t.co/JAmeOOM2nK

While the COVID-19 rapid test rollout was well intended, the unique nature of AK wasn't taken into consideration. Tests must be stored above 35 degrees, but today, in our only Arctic state, temps are well below that.

My full letter to the Admin: https://t.co/K70yu6eczZ https://t.co/BkPwQrOout

NEW: Within hours of @POTUS's at-home rapid test launch, I started hearing from Alaskans facing great difficulty placing orders. 

I sent a letter to the @WhiteHouse COVID-19 Response Coordinator seeking answers for my constituents: https://t.co/JDtN1YZmca https://t.co/9iTN0y1dJk

I have heard from many Alaskans with urgent questions and concerns about securing COVID-19 rapid tests. 

Testing kits have been in short supply, but STARTING TODAY there are two new options to help Alaskans get COVID-19 rapid antigen tests. 

Read more: https://t.co/fyjaTy9MPW

‚úÖAlaskans‚úÖ

Starting TODAY, four COVID-19 rapid tests kits can be ordered through @USPS here: https://t.co/kbIZFP2Zkz

Additionally, private health plans are now required to reimburse policyholders for rapid tests purchased after 1/15/22. More info here: https://t.co/5D8ZG8SSCx https://t.co/vU7AWnc8rI

Dr. King was committed to public service. In Alaska, we always look out for one another. But no matter where you are, I encourage you to honor Dr. King today by strengthening the bonds of fellowship with your neighbors.

These events are a vital part of American history & it's crucial to continue telling this story for generations to come. My 1996 bill also established the Selma to Montgomery National Historic Trail, which continues to honor the history and mission of the Civil Rights Movement.
Dr. King and my former colleague, the late Congressman John Lewis, famously helped lead the 1965 Selma to Montgomery March in defiance of segregation and racial inequality.

In 1996, as Natural Resources Chairman, it was my honor to author the bill authorizing the Martin Luther King, Jr Memorial in D.C.

Each year, millions of people visit the memorial to learn about his life & legacy, inspiring them to continue his work. https://t.co/kB5a3YgaSz https://t.co/XWw3c0jjWw

On Martin Luther King Jr Day, we honor one of our nation's greatest trailblazers. Dr. King's relentless fight for civil rights and equality changed the course of our country and helped push us closer towards the Constitution's promise of "a more perfect union." #MLKDay https://t.co/EYnaSoaf19

Too many lives have been ruined by minor marijuana offenses. States w/legal cannabis should be empowered to expunge records with these minor crimes. I'm cosponsoring the HOPE Act to fund state expungement programs & roll back damage from the War on Drugs: https://t.co/tLEAwiDkWX https://t.co/F7FVlrGCdZ

America's bridges are central to our competitiveness & I've always supported big, bold investments in this vital infrastructure. I'm pleased to see the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law providing the largest investment in US bridges since the the interstate highway system's creation. https://t.co/vKvVb3JXEW

This funding is just the tip of the iceberg in what will prove to be game-changing infrastructure investments in AK. I want to remind the rest of our nation that Denali is open in 2022 and we hope you will consider experiencing our great outdoors and everything AK has to offer. https://t.co/a2Qz1r5A5I

NEW: @SecDebHaaland personally called me to let me know $25 MILLION from the Bipartisan #Infrastructure Law is on its way to Alaska! Laine Welch is an Alaskan institution. For 33 years she's been keeping listeners informed on our fisheries and the public policy decisions impacting them. We'll miss her voice on the radio, but I wish her all the best in whatever comes next! üêüüé£ https://t.co/LJGFnlpn7e

I want to hear from you. Click here to take my constituent survey on the NPR-A: https://t.co/VS9uKPssCw
This reversion, championed by bureaucrats thousands of miles away from the NPR-A, is dead wrong. I condemn this disastrous move and will continue standing up for Alaska‚Äôs workers.

Heavy-handed D.C. bureaucrats are at it again; this time, they‚Äôre targeting the hardworking men and women of the North Slope ‚Äì including many union members. https://t.co/ah5Gk8roJl

I guess we couldn't even afford real bookshelves for photo backdrops the last time inflation was this high!

#Inflation is an invisible tax on working families & it raises the cost of putting food on the table. As families do, the federal gov't must get its fiscal house in order. https://t.co/wzjUxhpDdf https://t.co/vhmUR3F5XW

I thank my friend @RepPerlmutter for his service on the bipartisan Cannabis Caucus and long-time advocacy for the SAFE Banking Act. 

Ed, let me be blunt: your work has set the stage to get SAFE Banking across the finish line. Let's get it done.

.@lisamurkowski & I recently joined @AARPAlaska for a tele-town hall on the landmark bipartisan #infrastructure bill we worked together to get signed into law. Thank you to all the Alaskans who brought great questions!

Thanks Stephanie Thompson of Alexander Creek for a great meeting! The Native people in Alexander Creek have been denied recognition under ANCSA as a Village Corp for too long. I've intro'd a bill to fix this injustice so they have the same opportunities as other AK Native Corps. https://t.co/eIyA1uBLsO
Please join me in keeping his family in your prayers during this difficult time.

I'm proud to have worked with him so closely over the years, but I am even prouder to have called him my friend. Although he may no longer be with us, his work and the work of the @Rasmuson Foundation will continue to support and inspire future Alaskans for generations to come.

He wore many hats  -- Ed was not only a successful banker who helped expand economic development across Alaska, but also a steadfast philanthropist. He never stopped giving back to our state & made a difference in the lives of communities from every corner of Alaska.

I am sad to learn of the passing of my good friend, Ed Rasmuson. Ed loved our great state, and always kept Alaska as his guiding focus in his countless endeavors. 
https://t.co/mDRlALGm61

I want to thank all AFN 2021 attendees for their continued leadership on behalf of Alaska Natives. I'm proud to serve as your partner in the House. As always, if you‚Äôd like to share your views on legislation before Congress, don't hesitate to contact me: https://t.co/8XtYRtw1L2

My amendment would help to end the disproportionately high levels of violence against Indigenous women by ensuring Alaska Native villages have jurisdiction for the Alaska tribal jurisdiction pilot program.

I‚Äôll continue working hard this Congress to fight the MMIWG crisis. Earlier this year, I helped the House reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act (#VAWA). I am pleased that this bill retains my amendment to help combat violence directed at Native American women.

This bill, now law, requires the establishment of a commission that includes Tribal, state, & local officials, in addition to Tribal judges & healthcare providers to help law enforcement better respond to the unique needs of Indigenous communities as they investigate MMIWG cases.
Last year, we also passed the Not Invisible Act, which I was proud to help introduce alongside my friend, then-Congresswoman Deb Haaland.
Too many families do not feel comfortable reporting missing loved ones because of a lack of culturally appropriate law enforcement training. Savanna's Act will help address this.

Additionally, it requires the DOJ to offer culturally specific training for law enforcement to help them better understand what their role is in MMIWG cases, and to help them tailor responses to Alaska Native and Native American communities.

Because of its passage, the Department of Justice (DOJ) is now required to create a task force to bring law enforcement, first responders, and Indigenous communities together to get on the same page to respond to a missing person case.
Last Congress, I helped lead House passage of Savanna's Act and the Not Invisible Act, which were signed into law. Savannah's Act represents a significant step in the right direction.

As Ranking Member of the Subcommittee for Indigenous Peoples of The United States and Vice-Chair of the House Native American Caucus, I want to briefly share an update on what I'm doing in Congress to combat the MMIWG epidemic.

#AFN 2021 has concluded, but there is still work to do. 

Too many Alaska Native communities have experienced deep pain caused by the tragedy of the national epidemic of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (#MMIWG). @NativeFed [üßµTHREAD] https://t.co/TmGSFIwtxy

I‚Äôve driven tanks, captained boats, mushed dogs, & flown planes. I've always stood up for our state‚Äôs transportation needs, & it is my hope that this bipartisan bill helps America continue to lead the world & better compete with our adversaries. More: https://t.co/NTIrQT9832 https://t.co/3dxdGVR3ey

I'm grateful to everyone who helped make this bill a reality, including our own Senator @lisamurkowski & @SenDanSullivan. I urge @POTUS to swiftly sign it into law so that we can get people to work, and build the infrastructure future our great nation deserves.

I've made it clear that I don't like the way this bill made it to the floor. It should've moved via regular order, allowing T&I Chair DeFazio & RM Graves to improve it. But there are no do-overs now, & too much of our infrastructure is already in the 11th hour of its usefulness.

Ensuring the Commission has the resources necessary to carry out its mission has always been one of my highest priorities. The bipartisan bill we passed today authorizes $75 million for the Denali Commission to keep up its hard work on behalf of Alaskans.

The Denali Commission is a crucially important agency to Alaskans. Since its creation by Congress in 1998, the Denali Commission has done needed work to provide utilities, infrastructure, and economic support throughout Alaska.

The COVID-19 pandemic shined a spotlight on the need for fast, reliable broadband. I welcome the bill's investments in our state's rural broadband connectivity, and I am confident that students, businesses, and families will benefit greatly from millions in broadband funding.
In addition, this legislation takes needed action to fund the Coast Guard's unfunded priority list, which will benefit Coast Guard service members in places like Kodiak, Seward, and Ketchikan.

Alaska stands to receive $250 million for remote and subsistence harbor construction, which will help rural communities off the road system receive a true lifeline. From food and gasoline to medical supplies and raw materials, ports are essential for Alaskans in remote areas.

Today's bipartisan infrastructure bill builds on this progress by providing $1 billion for essential ferry service to rural Alaskan communities. Additionally, it provides $73 million for the construction of new ferries for Alaska.

The AK Marine Highway System (AMHS) is an integral part of SE's transportation portfolio. I have been a long-time supporter of the AMHS. In fact, it was my own bill that made it possible for AMHS to qualify as a "highway" for the purposes of federal funding in the first place.

The bipartisan infrastructure bill authorizes $3.5 bil in federal highway funding for Alaska over 5 years. This means we can rebuild, maintain, & construct new roads & highways to better serve Alaskans. The benefits for our state do not stop at highway funding alone.

Alaska is unlike any other state in the union. Our unique, often harsh terrain means we have very different infrastructure needs than the Lower 48. I am pleased by the historic investments this legislation makes in Alaska.
But I will be honest: when I take a look at some of our roads, bridges, and ports, I do not like what I see.

Our country is an economic powerhouse in no small part due to our historical support for infrastructure projects. Perhaps more than anyone else, Alaskans know just how vital reliable infrastructure is to stay connected with one another and secure upward economic mobility.

Late last night, I proudly voted in support of the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, commonly referred to as the bipartisan #infrastructure bill. I want to take a moment to update you on why this legislation is so crucial to Alaska. [üßµTHREAD] https://t.co/GK9QhrWnOU
This vote has been open so long it's about to become Dean of the House. What's taking so long? Let's get going! https://t.co/hOQwC2y4dI

By submitting a photograph, you agree to allowing the Office of Congressman Don Young to use your work on social media with attribution.

‚úîÔ∏èA short description (no more than 5-8 sentences) of the picture and how it captures the spirit of Alaska.

Please attach your photo in an email and send it to akphotos@mail.house.gov

Whether the subject is a towering mountain peak or a traditional Alaska Native gathering, I encourage you to submit your original work for the chance to be shared on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram as part of this virtual exhibit.

In Congress, I have been a steadfast supporter of the arts and humanities. As a medium, photography allows us to capture still images of daily life and preserve them for future generations to enjoy and learn from.

üì∏Today, I am proud to announce a new initiative: Picturesque Alaska!üì∏

My bill offers a win-win for Alaska Natives and tribal communities across the country. Read about it here: https://t.co/rjnRVJKhW4

However, it is time to update the U.S. law that allowed a foreign government to cripple our tourism economy in the first place. That is why I have introduced the Tribal Tourism Sovereignty Act, which will allow cruise ships to bypass Canada if they so choose.
The cruising industry is critical to both Alaska and British Columbia's economies, and we can continue to mutually prosper if both nations work in good faith.
The abbreviated 2021 cruise season in Alaska demonstrated without a doubt that cruise ships can operate safely with smart COVID-19 mitigation measures in place.

This week, our Canadian neighbors lifted their ban on cruise vessels in their waters. I welcome this development, but we must secure a long-term agreement with Canada to prevent future port closures from threatening our economy. [üßµTHREADüßµ]
